awd_titl_txt: Conference on Symmetry, Invariants, and their Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The conference "Symmetry, Invariants, and their Applications" will take place on August 3-5, 2022 at Dalhousie University in Nova Scotia, Canada, both in person and on line. The award funds will help defray travel and local expenses of US-based participants, prioritizing support for graduate students, postdocs, early-career researchers, and members of underrepresented groups.  Symmetries are transformations that keep a geometric object invariant, that is, unchanged.  Many biological, chemical, physical, and man-made structures exhibit symmetries as fundamental design principles or essential aspects of their functioning.  In geometry, the Erlangen program set forward by Felix Klein in 1872 clearly identified the importance of symmetry and invariants in the geometrical study of manifolds.  Symmetry group methods are among the most powerful techniques available for finding closed-form solutions to nonlinear differential equations appearing in physics, engineering, and economics. Symmetries are essential in our understanding of conservation laws in physics and occur in a wide variety of modern applications including computer vision, automatic assembly of broken objects such as eggshells, pottery, and bones, and more.

One of the central themes of the conference is the application of Lie point symmetries and their extensions to obtain closed-form solutions of differential, finite difference, differential-difference, integro-differential, stochastic, and fractional differential equations. This theme intertwines with the investigation of differential, integral, and joint invariants together with their applications in general relativity, computer vision, automated assembly problems, geometric numerical integration, and other fields. These invariants can be computed using the method of moving frames where the recurrence relations unlock the structure of the algebra of invariants.  Moving frames play a crucial role in solving equivalence problems and studying geometric spaces, invariant geometric flows, and integrable systems.

Conference website: https://www.math.mun.ca/movingframes2022/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The three-day conference at Dalhousie University in Nova Scotia, Canada, brought together a diverse group of researchers from around the world to discuss the latest developments in the theory and applications of symmetry, invariants, and moving frames. There were 68 conference attendees among which 35 participated in-person and 33 remotely.  Of the in-person participants, 19 were graduate students or postdocs. The remaining participants were university faculty and members of research institutes. The NSF conference grant provided travel support for 18 US-based attendees, nine of which were speakers or organizers and nine were participants. The conference also received support from the Atlantic Association for Research in the Mathematical Sciences (AARMS) of Canada and Komorebi company of Spain.


The talks and posters presented at the conference have demonstrated that the study of symmetries and their invariants is a rich and vibrant field of research in terms of applications and theory. Results on applications that were presented include biology, chemistry, computer science, engineering, physics, STEM education, and differential equations. Examples of results presented include the linearization problem of control systems with applications in aviation, the numerical study of the heart and brain to understand the mechanisms that lead to heart arrhythmia and brain dementia, the use of invariants in the study of black holes in general relativity and their applications to object recognition in computer vision, and modeling student engagement using optimal control theory. Some of the theoretical results presented include solving the equivalence problem for G-structures through the structure of Lie algebroids and Lie groupoids, the interplay between integrable systems and symmetry, and improved convergence rates for optimization problems on manifolds.


Presentation slides and posters are available on the conference website https://www.math.mun.ca/~movingframes2022/. Furthermore, a special issue of the Symmetry, Integrability and Geometry: Methods and Applications (SIGMA) journal available at https://www.emis.de/journals/SIGMA/Olver.html is dedicated to the publication of papers related to the topics of the conference.


The broader impact of the conference includes the dissemination of the research results and ideas through the talks, posters, conference website, and the special issue of the SIGMA journal.  Many of the results have potential applications in fields outside mathematics. The conference provided training and networking opportunities, in particular, to junior researchers and researchers from universities without a graduate program.
